subsection.content: An arbitral tribunal may extend the time or period referred to in subsection (1), or the time or period extended under subsection (4), for a further period and on the terms that it thinks fit, and the tribunal may do so even though that time or period or the extended time or period has expired.
This section does not affect the operation of section 14 or any other enactment that limits the period for commencing arbitral proceedings.

The power conferred on an arbitral tribunal by this section is exercisable by the Court if at the relevant time there is not in existence an arbitral tribunal that is capable of exercising that power.
An order of the Court made in exercise of its power conferred by subsection (7) is not subject to appeal.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Order to be made in case of delay in pursuing claims in arbitral proceedings

subsection.content: Unless otherwise expressed in an arbitration agreement, a party who has a claim under the agreement must, after the commencement of the arbitral proceedings, pursue that claim without unreasonable delay.

subsection.leadIn: Without affecting article 25 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, given effect to by section 53(1), the arbitral tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make an award dismissing a party’s claim; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may make an order prohibiting the party from commencing further arbitral proceedings in respect of the claim,

subsection.continued: if it is satisfied that the party has unreasonably delayed in pursuing the claim in the arbitral proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: The arbitral tribunal may make an award or order either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on its own initiative; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the application of any other party.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), delay is unreasonable if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it gives rise, or is likely to give rise, to a substantial risk that the issues in the claim will not be resolved fairly; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it has caused, or is likely to cause, serious prejudice to any other party.

subsection.content: The power conferred on an arbitral tribunal by this section is exercisable by the Court if there is not in existence an arbitral tribunal that is capable of exercising that power.
An award or order made by the Court in exercise of its power conferred by subsection (5) is not subject to appeal.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Special powers of Court in relation to arbitral proceedings

subsection.leadIn: On the application of any party, the Court may, in relation to any arbitral proceedings which have been or are to be commenced in or outside Hong Kong, make an order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: directing the inspection, photographing, preservation, custody, detention or sale of any relevant property by the arbitral tribunal, a party to the arbitral proceedings or an expert; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: directing samples to be taken from, observations to be made of, or experiments to be conducted on any relevant property.

subsection.content: Property is a relevant property for the purposes of subsection (1) if the property is the subject of the arbitral proceedings, or any question relating to the property has arisen in the arbitral proceedings.

The powers conferred by this section may be exercised by the Court irrespective of whether or not similar powers may be exercised by an arbitral tribunal under section 56 in relation to the same dispute.

subsection.leadIn: The Court may decline to make an order under this section in relation to a matter referred to in subsection (1) on the ground that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the matter is currently the subject of arbitral proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court considers it more appropriate for the matter to be dealt with by the arbitral tribunal.

subsection.content: An order made by the Court under this section may provide for the cessation of that order, in whole or in part, when the arbitral tribunal makes an order for the cessation.

In relation to arbitral proceedings which have been or are to be commenced outside Hong Kong, the Court may make an order under subsection (1) only if the arbitral proceedings are capable of giving rise to an arbitral award (whether interim or final) that may be enforced in Hong Kong under this Ordinance or any other Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (6) applies even if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the subject matter of the arbitral proceedings would not, apart from that subsection, give rise to a cause of action over which the Court would have jurisdiction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the order sought is not ancillary or incidental to any arbitral proceedings in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: In exercising the power under subsection (1) in relation to arbitral proceedings outside Hong Kong, the Court must have regard to the fact that the power is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ancillary to the arbitral proceedings outside Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of facilitating the process of a court or arbitral tribunal outside Hong Kong that has primary jurisdiction over the arbitral proceedings.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (10), an order or decision of the Court under this section is not subject to appeal.
The leave of the Court is required for any appeal from an order of the Court under subsection (1) for the sale of any relevant property.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Enforcement of orders and directions of arbitral tribunal

subsection.content: An order or direction made, whether in or outside Hong Kong, in relation to arbitral proceedings by an arbitral tribunal is enforceable in the same manner as an order or direction of the Court that has the same effect, but only with the leave of the Court.

Leave to enforce an order or direction made outside Hong Kong is not to be granted, unless the party seeking to enforce it can demonstrate that it belongs to a type or description of order or direction that may be made in Hong Kong in relation to arbitral proceedings by an arbitral tribunal.
If leave is granted under subsection (1), the Court may enter judgment in terms of the order or direction.
A decision of the Court to grant or refuse to grant leave under subsection (1) is not subject to appeal.
An order or direction referred to in this section includes an interim measure.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Power of Court to order recovery of arbitrator’s fees

subsection.leadIn: Where an arbitrator’s mandate terminates under article 13 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, given effect to by section 26, or under article 14 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, given effect to by section 27, then on the application of any party, the Court, in its discretion and having regard to the conduct of the arbitrator and any other relevant circumstances—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may order that the arbitrator is not entitled to receive the whole or part of the arbitrator’s fees or expenses; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may order that the arbitrator must repay the whole or part of the fees or expenses already paid to the arbitrator.

subsection.content: An order of the Court under subsection (1) is not subject to appeal.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Representation and preparation work
section.leadIn: Section 44 (Penalty for unlawfully practising as a barrister or notary public), section 45 (Unqualified person not to act as solicitor) and section 47 (Unqualified person not to prepare certain instruments, etc.) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159) do not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: arbitral proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the giving of advice and the preparation of documents for the purposes of arbitral proceedings; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: any other thing done in relation to arbitral proceedings, except where it is done in connection with court proceedings—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: arising out of an arbitration agreement; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: arising in the course of, or resulting from, arbitral proceedings.

part.name: P8
part.heading: Making of Award and Termination of Proceedings

section.name: s64
section.heading: Article 28 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Rules applicable to substance of dispute)
section.content:
Article 28 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, the text of which is set out below, has effect—
“Article 28. Rules applicable to substance of dispute (1) The arbitral tribunal shall decide the dispute in accordance with such rules of law as are chosen by the parties as applicable to the substance of the dispute. Any designation of the law or legal system of a given State shall be construed, unless otherwise expressed, as directly referring to the substantive law of that State and not to its conflict of laws rules. (2) Failing any designation by the parties, the arbitral tribunal shall apply the law determined by the conflict of laws rules which it considers applicable. (3) The arbitral tribunal shall decide ex aequo et bono or as amiable compositeur only if the parties have expressly authorized it to do so. (4) In all cases, the arbitral tribunal shall decide in accordance with the terms of the contract and shall take into account the usages of the trade applicable to the transaction.”.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Article 29 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Decision-making by panel of arbitrators)
section.content:
Article 29 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, the text of which is set out below, has effect—
“Article 29. Decision-making by panel of arbitrators
In arbitral proceedings with more than one arbitrator, any decision of the arbitral tribunal shall be made, unless otherwise agreed by the parties, by a majority of all its members. However, questions of procedure may be decided by a presiding arbitrator, if so authorized by the parties or all members of the arbitral tribunal.”.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Article 30 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Settlement)

subsection.content: Article 30 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, the text of which is set out below, has effect—

(1) If, during arbitral proceedings, the parties settle the dispute, the arbitral tribunal shall terminate the proceedings and, if requested by the parties and not objected to by the arbitral tribunal, record the settlement in the form of an arbitral award on agreed terms.

(2) An award on agreed terms shall be made in accordance with the provisions of article 31 and shall state that it is an award. Such an award has the same status and effect as any other award on the merits of the case.”.

If, in a case other than that referred to in article 30 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, given effect to by subsection (1), the parties to an arbitration agreement settle their dispute and enter into an agreement in writing containing the terms of settlement (settlement agreement), the settlement agreement is, for the purposes of its enforcement, to be treated as an arbitral award.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Article 31 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Form and contents of award)

subsection.content: Article 31 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, the text of which is set out below, has effect—

(1) The award shall be made in writing and shall be signed by the arbitrator or arbitrators. In arbitral proceedings with more than one arbitrator, the signatures of the majority of all members of the arbitral tribunal shall suffice, provided that the reason for any omitted signature is stated.
(2) The award shall state the reasons upon which it is based, unless the parties have agreed that no reasons are to be given or the award is an award on agreed terms under article 30.
(3) The award shall state its date and the place of arbitration as determined in accordance with article 20(1). The award shall be deemed to have been made at that place.
(4) After the award is made, a copy signed by the arbitrators in accordance with paragraph (1) of this article shall be delivered to each party.”.
Article 31(4) of the UNCITRAL Model Law, given effect to by subsection (1), has effect subject to section 77.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Article 32 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Termination of proceedings)
section.content: Article 32 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, the text of which is set out below, has effect— “Article 32. Termination of proceedings (1) The arbitral proceedings are terminated by the final award or by an order of the arbitral tribunal in accordance with paragraph (2) of this article. (2) The arbitral tribunal shall issue an order for the termination of the arbitral proceedings when:(a) the claimant withdraws his claim, unless the respondent objects thereto and the arbitral tribunal recognizes a legitimate interest on his part in obtaining a final settlement of the dispute;(b) the parties agree on the termination of the proceedings;(c) the arbitral tribunal finds that the continuation of the proceedings has for any other reason become unnecessary or impossible. (3) The mandate of the arbitral tribunal terminates with the termination of the arbitral proceedings, subject to the provisions of articles 33 and 34(4).”.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Article 33 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Correction and interpretation of award; additional award)

subsection.content: Article 33 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, the text of which is set out below, has effect—

quotedStructure.content: “Article 33. Correction and interpretation of award; additional award

subsection.leadIn: (1) Within thirty days of receipt of the award, unless another period of time has been agreed upon by the parties:

paragraph.content: (a) a party, with notice to the other party, may request the arbitral tribunal to correct in the award any errors in computation, any clerical or typographical errors or any errors of similar nature;
(b) if so agreed by the parties, a party, with notice to the other party, may request the arbitral tribunal to give an interpretation of a specific point or part of the award.

subsection.continued: If the arbitral tribunal considers the request to be justified, it shall make the correction or give the interpretation within thirty days of receipt of the request. The interpretation shall form part of the award.

subsection.content: (2) The arbitral tribunal may correct any error of the type referred to in paragraph (1)(a) of this article on its own initiative within thirty days of the date of the award.

(3) Unless otherwise agreed by the parties, a party, with notice to the other party, may request, within thirty days of receipt of the award, the arbitral tribunal to make an additional award as to claims presented in the arbitral proceedings but omitted from the award. If the arbitral tribunal considers the request to be justified, it shall make the additional award within sixty days.
(4) The arbitral tribunal may extend, if necessary, the period of time within which it shall make a correction, interpretation or an additional award under paragraph (1) or (3) of this article.
(5) The provisions of article 31 shall apply to a correction or interpretation of the award or to an additional award.”.

subsection.leadIn: The arbitral tribunal has the power to make other changes to an arbitral award which are necessitated by or consequential on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the correction of any error in the award; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the interpretation of any point or part of the award,

subsection.continued: under article 33 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, given effect to by subsection (1).

subsection.content: The arbitral tribunal may review an award of costs within 30 days of the date of the award if, when making the award, the tribunal was not aware of any information relating to costs (including any offer for settlement) which it should have taken into account.
On a review under subsection (3), the arbitral tribunal may confirm, vary or correct the award of costs.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Award of remedy or relief

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2) and section 103D(6), an arbitral tribunal may, in deciding a dispute, award any remedy or relief that could have been ordered by the Court if the dispute had been the subject of civil proceedings in the Court. (Amended 5 of 2017 s. 4)

Unless otherwise agreed by the parties, the arbitral tribunal has the same power as the Court to order specific performance of any contract, other than a contract relating to land or any interest in land.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Awards on different aspects of matters
section.content: Unless otherwise agreed by the parties, an arbitral tribunal may make more than one award at different times on different aspects of the matters to be determined.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Time for making award

subsection.content: Unless otherwise agreed by the parties, an arbitral tribunal has the power to make an award at any time.

The time, if any, limited for making an award, whether under this Ordinance or otherwise, may from time to time be extended by order of the Court on the application of any party, whether that time has expired or not.
An order of the Court under subsection (2) is not subject to appeal.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Effect of award

subsection.leadIn: Unless otherwise agreed by the parties, an award made by an arbitral tribunal pursuant to an arbitration agreement is final and binding both on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the parties; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person claiming through or under any of the parties.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not affect the right of a person to challenge the award—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as provided for in section 26 or 81, section 4 or 5 of Schedule 2, or any other provision of this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: otherwise by any available arbitral process of appeal or review.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Arbitral tribunal may award costs of arbitral proceedings

subsection.content: An arbitral tribunal may include in an award directions with respect to the costs of arbitral proceedings (including the fees and expenses of the tribunal).

The arbitral tribunal may, having regard to all relevant circumstances (including the fact, if appropriate, that a written offer of settlement of the dispute concerned has been made), direct in the award under subsection (1) to whom and by whom and in what manner the costs are to be paid.

The arbitral tribunal may also, in its discretion, order costs (including the fees and expenses of the tribunal) to be paid by a party in respect of a request made by any of the parties for an order or direction (including an interim measure).
The arbitral tribunal may direct that the costs ordered under subsection (3) are to be paid forthwith or at the time that the tribunal may otherwise specify.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 75, the arbitral tribunal must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: assess the amount of costs to be awarded or ordered to be paid under this section (other than the fees and expenses of the tribunal); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: award or order those costs (including the fees and expenses of the tribunal).

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (7), the arbitral tribunal is not obliged to follow the scales and practices adopted by the court on taxation when assessing the amount of costs (other than the fees and expenses of the tribunal) under subsection (5).

subsection.leadIn: The arbitral tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must only allow costs that are reasonable having regard to all the circumstances; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unless otherwise agreed by the parties, may allow costs incurred in the preparation of the arbitral proceedings prior to the commencement of the arbitration.

subsection.content: A provision of an arbitration agreement to the effect that the parties, or any of the parties, must pay their own costs in respect of arbitral proceedings arising under the agreement is void.
A provision referred to in subsection (8) is not void if it is part of an agreement to submit to arbitration a dispute that had arisen before the agreement was made.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Taxation of costs of arbitral proceedings (other than fees and expenses of arbitral tribunal)

subsection.content: Without affecting section 74(1) and (2), if the parties have agreed that the costs of arbitral proceedings are to be taxed by the court, then unless the arbitral tribunal otherwise directs in an award, the award is deemed to have included the tribunal’s directions that the costs (other than the fees and expenses of the tribunal) are to be taxed by the court on the party and party basis in accordance with rule 28(2) of Order 62 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A). (Amended 7 of 2013 s. 7)
On taxation by the court, the arbitral tribunal must make an additional award of costs reflecting the result of such taxation.
A decision of the court on taxation is not subject to appeal.
This section does not apply to costs ordered to be paid under section 74(3).

section.name: s76
section.heading: Costs in respect of unqualified person
section.content: Section 50 (No costs for unqualified person) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159) does not apply to the recovery of costs in an arbitration.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Determination of arbitral tribunal’s fees and expenses in case of dispute

subsection.content: An arbitral tribunal may refuse to deliver an award to the parties unless full payment of the fees and expenses of the tribunal is made.

subsection.leadIn: If the arbitral tribunal refuses to deliver an award to the parties under subsection (1), a party may apply to the Court, which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: may order the tribunal to deliver the award on the payment into the Court by the applicant of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the fees and expenses demanded; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a lesser amount that the Court may specify;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may order that the amount of the fees and expenses payable to the tribunal is to be determined by the means and on the terms that the Court may direct; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: may order that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the fees and expenses as determined under paragraph (b) to be payable are to be paid to the tribunal out of the money paid into the Court; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the balance of the money paid into the Court, if any, is to be paid out to the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the amount of the fees and expenses payable is the amount which the applicant is liable to pay—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: under section 78; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under any agreement relating to the payment of the arbitrators; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the fees and expenses of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an expert appointed under article 26 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, given effect to by section 54(1); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an assessor appointed under section 54(2),

paragraph.continued: are to be treated as the fees and expenses of the arbitral tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: No application under subsection (2) may be made if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is any available arbitral process for appeal or review of the amount of the fees or expenses demanded; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the total amount of the fees and expenses demanded has been fixed by a written agreement between a party and the arbitrators.

subsection.content: Subsections (1) to (4) also apply to any arbitral or other institution or person vested by the parties with powers in relation to the delivery of the arbitral tribunal’s award.

If subsections (1) to (4) so apply under subsection (5), the references to the fees and expenses of the arbitral tribunal are to be construed as including the fees and expenses of that institution or person.

If an application is made to the Court under subsection (2), enforcement of the award (when delivered to the parties), but only in so far as it relates to the fees or expenses of the arbitral tribunal, must be stayed until the application has been disposed of under this section.
An arbitrator is entitled to appear and be heard on any determination under this section.

If the amount of the fees and expenses determined under subsection (2)(b) is different from the amount previously awarded by the arbitral tribunal, the tribunal must amend the previous award to reflect the result of the determination.
An order of the Court under this section is not subject to appeal.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Liability to pay fees and expenses of arbitral tribunal

subsection.content: The parties to proceedings before an arbitral tribunal are jointly and severally liable to pay to the tribunal reasonable fees and expenses, if any, of the tribunal that are appropriate in the circumstances.
Subsection (1) has effect subject to any order of the Court made under section 62 or any other relevant provision of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: This section does not affect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the liability of the parties as among themselves to pay the costs of the arbitral proceedings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any contractual right or obligation relating to payment of the fees and expenses of the arbitral tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: In this section, a reference to an arbitral tribunal includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a member of the tribunal who has ceased to act; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an umpire who has not yet replaced members of the tribunal.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Arbitral tribunal may award interest

subsection.leadIn: Unless otherwise agreed by the parties, an arbitral tribunal may, in the arbitral proceedings before it, award simple or compound interest from the dates, at the rates, and with the rests that the tribunal considers appropriate, subject to section 80, for any period ending not later than the date of payment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on money awarded by the tribunal in the arbitral proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on money claimed in, and outstanding at the commencement of, the arbitral proceedings but paid before the award is made; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: on costs awarded or ordered by the tribunal in the arbitral proceedings.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not affect any other power of an arbitral tribunal to award interest.
A reference in subsection (1)(a) to money awarded by the tribunal includes an amount payable in consequence of a declaratory award by the tribunal.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Interest on money or costs awarded or ordered in arbitral proceedings

subsection.content: Interest is payable on money awarded by an arbitral tribunal from the date of the award at the judgment rate, except when the award otherwise provides.

subsection.leadIn: Interest is payable on costs awarded or ordered by an arbitral tribunal from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the award or order on costs; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which costs ordered are directed to be paid forthwith,

subsection.continued: at the judgment rate, except when the award or order on costs otherwise provides.

subsection.def: In this section, judgment rate (判定利率) means the rate of interest determined by the Chief Justice under section 49(1)(b) (Interest on judgments) of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4).

section.name: s81
section.heading: Article 34 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Application for setting aside as exclusive recourse against arbitral award)

subsection.content: Article 34 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, the text of which is set out below, has effect subject to section 13(5)—

quotedStructure.content: “Article 34. Application for setting aside as exclusive recourse against arbitral award

subsection.content: (1) Recourse to a court against an arbitral award may be made only by an application for setting aside in accordance with paragraphs (2) and (3) of this article.

subsection.leadIn: (2) An arbitral award may be set aside by the court specified in article 6 only if:

paragraph.leadIn: (a) the party making the application furnishes proof that:

subparagraph.content: a party to the arbitration agreement referred to in article 7 was under some incapacity; or the said agreement is not valid under the law to which the parties have subjected it or, failing any indication thereon, under the law of this State; or
the party making the application was not given proper notice of the appointment of an arbitrator or of the arbitral proceedings or was otherwise unable to present his case; or

the award deals with a dispute not contemplated by or not falling within the terms of the submission to arbitration, or contains decisions on matters beyond the scope of the submission to arbitration, provided that, if the decisions on matters submitted to arbitration can be separated from those not so submitted, only that part of the award which contains decisions on matters not submitted to arbitration may be set aside; or

the composition of the arbitral tribunal or the arbitral procedure was not in accordance with the agreement of the parties, unless such agreement was in conflict with a provision of this Law from which the parties cannot derogate, or, failing such agreement, was not in accordance with this Law; or

paragraph.leadIn: (b) the court finds that:

subparagraph.content: the subject-matter of the dispute is not capable of settlement by arbitration under the law of this State; or
the award is in conflict with the public policy of this State.

subsection.content: (3) An application for setting aside may not be made after three months have elapsed from the date on which the party making that application had received the award or, if a request had been made under article 33, from the date on which that request had been disposed of by the arbitral tribunal.

(4) The court, when asked to set aside an award, may, where appropriate and so requested by a party, suspend the setting aside proceedings for a period of time determined by it in order to give the arbitral tribunal an opportunity to resume the arbitral proceedings or to take such other action as in the arbitral tribunal’s opinion will eliminate the grounds for setting aside.”.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not affect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the power of the Court to set aside an arbitral award under section 26(5);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the right to challenge an arbitral award under section 4 of Schedule 2 (if applicable); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the right to appeal against an arbitral award on a question of law under section 5 of Schedule 2 (if applicable).

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2)(c), the Court does not have jurisdiction to set aside or remit an arbitral award on the ground of errors of fact or law on the face of the award.
The leave of the Court is required for any appeal from a decision of the Court under article 34 of the UNCITRAL Model Law, given effect to by subsection (1).

section.name: s82
section.heading: Article 35 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Recognition and enforcement)
section.content: Article 35 of the UNCITRAL Model Law does not have effect.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Article 36 of UNCITRAL Model Law (Grounds for refusing recognition or enforcement)
section.content: Article 36 of the UNCITRAL Model Law does not have effect.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Enforcement of arbitral awards

subsection.content: Subject to section 26(2), an award, whether made in or outside Hong Kong, in arbitral proceedings by an arbitral tribunal is enforceable in the same manner as a judgment of the Court that has the same effect, but only with the leave of the Court.
If leave is granted under subsection (1), the Court may enter judgment in terms of the award.
The leave of the Court is required for any appeal from a decision of the Court to grant or refuse leave to enforce an award under subsection (1).

section.name: s85
section.heading: Evidence to be produced for enforcement of arbitral awards
section.leadIn: The party seeking to enforce an arbitral award, whether made in or outside Hong Kong, which is not a Convention award, Mainland award or Macao award, must produce— (Amended 7 of 2013 s. 9)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the duly authenticated original award or a duly certified copy of it;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the original arbitration agreement or a duly certified copy of it; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the award or agreement is not in either or both of the official languages, a translation of it in either official language certified by an official or sworn translator or by a diplomatic or consular agent. (Replaced 7 of 2013 s. 9)

section.name: s86
section.heading: Refusal of enforcement of arbitral awards

subsection.leadIn: Enforcement of an award referred to in section 85 may be refused if the person against whom it is invoked proves—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a party to the arbitration agreement was under some incapacity (under the law applicable to that party); (Replaced 7 of 2013 s. 10)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that the arbitration agreement was not valid—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: under the law to which the parties subjected it; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: (if there was no indication of the law to which the arbitration agreement was subjected) under the law of the country where the award was made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that the person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: was not given proper notice of the appointment of the arbitrator or of the arbitral proceedings; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: was otherwise unable to present the person’s case;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (3), that the award—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: deals with a difference not contemplated by or not falling within the terms of the submission to arbitration; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: contains decisions on matters beyond the scope of the submission to arbitration;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: that the composition of the arbitral authority or the arbitral procedure was not in accordance with—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the agreement of the parties; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: (if there was no agreement) the law of the country where the arbitration took place; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: that the award—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has not yet become binding on the parties; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: has been set aside or suspended by a competent authority of the country in which, or under the law of which, it was made.

subsection.leadIn: Enforcement of an award referred to in section 85 may also be refused if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the award is in respect of a matter which is not capable of settlement by arbitration under the law of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it would be contrary to public policy to enforce the award; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for any other reason the court considers it just to do so.

subsection.content: If an award referred to in section 85 contains, apart from decisions on matters submitted to arbitration (arbitral decisions), decisions on matters not submitted to arbitration (unrelated decisions), the award may be enforced only in so far as it relates to the arbitral decisions that can be separated from the unrelated decisions. (Replaced 7 of 2013 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: If an application for setting aside or suspending an award referred to in section 85 has been made to a competent authority as mentioned in subsection (1)(f), the court before which enforcement of the award is sought— (Amended 7 of 2013 s .10)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may, if it thinks fit, adjourn the proceedings for the enforcement of the award; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may, on the application of the party seeking to enforce the award, order the person against whom the enforcement is invoked to give security.

subsection.content: A decision or order of the court under subsection (4) is not subject to appeal.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Enforcement of Convention awards

subsection.leadIn: A Convention award is, subject to this Division, enforceable in Hong Kong either—

paragraph.name: a

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the same manner as an award to which section 84 applies, and that section applies to a Convention award accordingly as if a reference in that section to an award were a Convention award. (Amended 7 of 2013 s. 11)

subsection.content: A Convention award which is enforceable as mentioned in subsection (1) is to be treated as binding for all purposes on the parties, and may accordingly be relied on by any of them by way of defence, set off or otherwise in any legal proceedings in Hong Kong. (Replaced 7 of 2013 s. 11)
A reference in this Division to enforcement of a Convention award is to be construed as including reliance on a Convention award.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is specified in the order,

Subsections (1) and (2) do not affect any other method of proving that a State or territory is a party to the New York Convention.

section.name: s98E
section.heading: Purposes
section.leadIn: The purposes of this Part are to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensure that third party funding of arbitration is not prohibited by particular common law doctrines; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for measures and safeguards in relation to third party funding of arbitration.

section.name: s98F
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: advisory body (諮詢機構) means the person appointed by the Secretary for Justice under section 98X(1);
arbitration (仲裁) includes the following proceedings under this Ordinance—(a)court proceedings;(b)proceedings before an emergency arbitrator; and(c)mediation proceedings;

arbitration body (仲裁機構)—(a)in relation to an arbitration (other than the proceedings mentioned in paragraphs (b) and (c))—means the arbitral tribunal or court, as the case may be;(b)in relation to proceedings before an emergency arbitrator—means the emergency arbitrator; or(c)in relation to mediation proceedings—means the mediator appointed under section 32 or referred to in section 33, as the case may be;
arbitration funding (仲裁資助), in relation to an arbitration, means money, or any other financial assistance, in relation to any costs of the arbitration;
authorized body (獲授權機構) means the person appointed by the Secretary for Justice under section 98X(2);
code of practice (實務守則) means the code of practice issued under Division 4 and as amended from time to time;
costs (費用), in relation to an arbitration, means the costs and expenses of the arbitration and includes—(a)pre-arbitration costs and expenses; and(b)the fees and expenses of the arbitration body;
emergency arbitrator (緊急仲裁員) has the meaning given by section 22A;
funded party (受資助方)—see section 98I;
funding agreement (資助協議)—see section 98H;
mediation proceedings (調解程序) means mediation proceedings referred to in section 32(3) or 33;
potential third party funder (潛在出資第三者) means a person who carries on any activity with a view to becoming a third party funder;

provision (提供)—(a)in relation to the provision of arbitration funding to a person (recipient)—includes the provision of the arbitration funding to another person (for example, to the recipient’s legal representative) at the recipient’s request; and(b)in relation to the provision of arbitration funding by a person (funder)—includes the provision of the arbitration funding by another person that is arranged by the funder;
third party funding of arbitration (第三者資助仲裁)—see section 98G.

section.name: s98G
section.heading: Meaning of third party funding of arbitration
section.leadIn: Third party funding of arbitration is the provision of arbitration funding for an arbitration—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: under a funding agreement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a funded party;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by a third party funder; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in return for the third party funder receiving a financial benefit only if the arbitration is successful within the meaning of the funding agreement.

section.name: s98H
section.heading: Meaning of funding agreement

subsection.leadIn: A funding agreement is an agreement for third party funding of arbitration that is— (Amended 6 of 2022 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: made between a funded party and a third party funder; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: made on or after the commencement date of Division 3.

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, a funding agreement is not to be construed to include an ORFS agreement for arbitration within the meaning of Part 10B. (Added 6 of 2022 s. 3)

section.name: s98I
section.heading: Meaning of funded party

subsection.leadIn: A funded party is a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is a party to an arbitration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who is a party to a funding agreement for the provision of arbitration funding for the arbitration to the person by a third party funder.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)(a), the reference to a party to an arbitration includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who is likely to be a party to an arbitration that is yet to commence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who was a party to an arbitration that has ended.

section.name: s98J
section.heading: Meaning of third party funder

subsection.leadIn: A third party funder is a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is a party to a funding agreement for the provision of arbitration funding for an arbitration to a funded party by the person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who does not have an interest recognized by law in the arbitration other than under the funding agreement.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)(b), the reference to a person who does not have an interest in an arbitration includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who does not have an interest in the matter about which an arbitration is yet to commence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who did not have an interest in an arbitration that has ended.

division.name: D3
division.heading: Third Party Funding of Arbitration Not Prohibited by Particular Common Law Offences or Tort

editorialNote.content: This Division has yet to apply in relation to a mediation mentioned in section 7A of the Mediation Ordinance (Cap. 620) (see L.N. 260 of 2018).

section.name: s98K
section.heading: Particular common law offences do not apply
section.content: The common law offences of maintenance (including the common law offence of champerty) and of being a common barrator do not apply in relation to third party funding of arbitration.

section.name: s98L
section.heading: Particular tort does not apply
section.content: The tort of maintenance (including the tort of champerty) does not apply in relation to third party funding of arbitration.

section.name: s98M
section.heading: Other illegality not affected
section.content: Sections 98K and 98L do not affect any rule of law as to the cases in which a contract is to be treated as contrary to public policy or otherwise illegal.

section.name: s98N
section.heading: Limited application of Part 10A for non-Hong Kong arbitration
section.leadIn: Despite section 5, this Part applies in relation to an arbitration for which the place of arbitration is outside Hong Kong or there is no place of arbitration as if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the place of arbitration were in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the definition of costs in section 98F were replaced by the following—

continued.def: “costs (費用), in relation to an arbitration, means only the costs and expenses of services that are provided in Hong Kong in relation to the arbitration;”.

section.name: s98O
section.heading: Part 10A not applicable to lawyers acting for parties in arbitration

subsection.content: This Part does not apply in relation to the provision of arbitration funding to a party by a lawyer who, in the course of the lawyer’s legal practice, acts for any party in relation to the arbitration.

If a lawyer works for, or is a member of, a legal practice (however described or structured), the references in subsection (1) to “lawyer” include the legal practice and any other lawyer who works for, or is a member of, the legal practice.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: lawyer (律師) means—(a)a person who is enrolled on the roll of barristers kept under section 29 of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159);(b)a person who is enrolled on the roll of solicitors kept under section 5 of that Ordinance; or(c)a person who is qualified to practise the law of a jurisdiction other than Hong Kong, including a foreign lawyer as defined by section 2(1) of that Ordinance;
party (一方) means a party to an arbitration within the meaning of section 98I.

section.name: s98OA
section.heading: Part 10A not applicable to ORFS agreements for arbitration
section.content: This Part does not apply to an ORFS agreement for arbitration within the meaning of Part 10B.

section.name: s98P
section.heading: Code of practice may be issued

subsection.content: The authorized body may issue a code of practice setting out the practices and standards with which third party funders are ordinarily expected to comply in carrying on activities in connection with third party funding of arbitration.
The authorized body may amend or revoke the code of practice.
Section 98R applies in relation to an amendment or revocation of the code of practice in the same way as it applies in relation to the code of practice.

section.name: s98Q
section.heading: Content of code of practice

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 98P, the code of practice may, in setting out practices and standards, require third party funders to ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any promotional material in connection with third party funding of arbitration is clear and not misleading;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: funding agreements set out their key features, risks and terms, including—

subparagraph.content: the degree of control that third party funders will have in relation to an arbitration;

whether, and to what extent, third party funders (or persons associated with the third party funders) will be liable to funded parties for adverse costs, insurance premiums, security for costs and other financial liabilities; and
when, and on what basis, parties to funding agreements may terminate the funding agreements or third party funders may withhold arbitration funding;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: funded parties obtain independent legal advice on funding agreements before entering into them;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: third party funders provide to funded parties the name and contact details of the advisory body;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: third party funders have a sufficient minimum amount of capital;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: third party funders have effective procedures for addressing potential, actual or perceived conflicts of interest and the procedures enhance the protection of funded parties;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: third party funders have effective procedures for addressing complaints against them by funded parties and the procedures allow funded parties to obtain and enforce meaningful remedies for legitimate complaints;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: third party funders follow the procedures mentioned in paragraphs (f) and (g);

paragraph.leadIn: third party funders submit annual returns to the advisory body on—

subparagraph.content: any complaints against them by funded parties received during the reporting periods; and
any findings by a court or arbitral tribunal of their failure to comply with the code of practice or Division 5; and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: third party funders provide to the advisory body any other information it reasonably requires.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the code of practice may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specify terms to be included, or not to be included, in funding agreements; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify what is to be included, or not to be included, in order to have effective procedures.

subsection.leadIn: The code of practice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be of general or special application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may make different provisions for different circumstances and provide for different cases or classes of cases.

section.name: s98R
section.heading: Process for issuing code of practice

subsection.leadIn: Before issuing a code of practice, the authorized body must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: consult the public about the proposed code of practice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: publish a notice to inform the public of the proposed code of practice.

subsection.content: In preparing the proposed code of practice for public consultation, the authorized body may consult a person with knowledge or experience of arbitration or third party funding of arbitration.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must state the following information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the purpose and general effect of the proposed code of practice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: how a copy of the proposed code of practice may be inspected; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that written submissions by any person about the proposed code of practice may be made to the authorized body before a specified time.

subsection.content: After considering all written submissions made before the specified time, the authorized body may issue the code of practice (with or without revision) by publishing it in the Gazette.
The code of practice comes into operation on the day on which it is published in the Gazette under subsection (4).
The code of practice is not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s98S
section.heading: Non-compliance with code of practice

subsection.content: A failure to comply with a provision of the code of practice does not, of itself, render any person liable to any judicial or other proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: However—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the code of practice is admissible in evidence in proceedings before any court or arbitral tribunal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any compliance, or failure to comply, with a provision of the code of practice may be taken into account by any court or arbitral tribunal if it is relevant to a question being decided by the court or arbitral tribunal.

editorialNote.content: This Division has yet to apply in relation to a mediation mentioned in section 7A of the Mediation Ordinance (Cap. 620) (see L.N. 260 of 2018).

section.name: s98T
section.heading: Communication of information for third party funding of arbitration

subsection.content: Despite section 18(1), information referred to in that section may be communicated by a party to a person for the purpose of having, or seeking, third party funding of arbitration from the person.

subsection.leadIn: However, the person may not further communicate anything communicated under subsection (1), unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the further communication is made—

subparagraph.content: to protect or pursue a legal right or interest of the person; or
to enforce or challenge an award made in the arbitration,

paragraph.continued: in legal proceedings before a court or other judicial authority in or outside Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the further communication is made to a professional adviser of the person for the purpose of obtaining advice in connection with the third party funding of arbitration.

subsection.content: If a further communication is made by a person to a professional adviser under subsection (2)(c), subsection (2) applies to the professional adviser as if the professional adviser were the person.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: communicate (傳達) includes publish or disclose.

section.name: s98U
section.heading: Disclosure about third party funding of arbitration

subsection.leadIn: If a funding agreement is made, the funded party must give written notice of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the fact that a funding agreement has been made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name of the third party funder.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a funding agreement made on or before the commencement of the arbitration—on the commencement of the arbitration; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a funding agreement made after the commencement of the arbitration—within 15 days after the funding agreement is made.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each other party to the arbitration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the arbitration body.

subsection.content: For subsection (3)(b), if there is no arbitration body for the arbitration at the time, or at the end of the period, specified in subsection (2) for giving the notice, the notice must instead be given to the arbitration body immediately after there is an arbitration body for the arbitration.

section.name: s98V
section.heading: Disclosure about end of third party funding of arbitration

subsection.leadIn: If a funding agreement ends (other than because of the end of the arbitration), the funded party must give written notice of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the fact that the funding agreement has ended; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date the funding agreement ended.

subsection.content: The notice must be given within 15 days after the funding agreement ends.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each other party to the arbitration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the arbitration body (if any).

section.name: s98W
section.heading: Non-compliance with Division 5

subsection.content: A failure to comply with this Division does not, of itself, render any person liable to any judicial or other proceedings.

However, any compliance, or failure to comply, with this Division may be taken into account by any court or arbitral tribunal if it is relevant to a question being decided by the court or arbitral tribunal.

section.name: s98X
section.heading: Appointment of advisory body and authorized body

subsection.content: The Secretary for Justice may, by notice published in the Gazette, appoint as the advisory body a person the Secretary for Justice considers appropriate to monitor and review the operation of this Part.
The Secretary for Justice may, by notice published in the Gazette, appoint as the authorized body a person the Secretary for Justice considers appropriate to exercise the powers under section 98P.

part.name: P10B
part.heading: Outcome Related Fee Structure Agreement for Arbitration

section.name: s98Y
section.heading: Purposes
section.leadIn: The purposes of this Part are to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide that an ORFS agreement for arbitration is not prohibited by the common law doctrines of maintenance, champerty and barratry;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for the validity and enforceability of ORFS agreements for arbitration that meet certain general and specific conditions; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide for measures and safeguards in relation to ORFS agreements for arbitration.

section.name: s98Z
section.heading: Part 10B not applicable to funding agreements
section.content: This Part does not apply to a funding agreement within the meaning of Part 10A.

section.name: s98ZA
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: advisory body (諮詢機構) means the person appointed by the Secretary for Justice under section 98ZT(1);
arbitration (仲裁) includes the following proceedings under this Ordinance—(a)court proceedings;(b)proceedings before an emergency arbitrator;(c)mediation proceedings;

arbitration body (仲裁機構)—(a)in relation to an arbitration (other than the proceedings mentioned in paragraphs (b) and (c))—means the arbitral tribunal or court, as the case may be;(b)in relation to proceedings before an emergency arbitrator—means the emergency arbitrator; or(c)in relation to mediation proceedings—means the mediator appointed under section 32 or referred to in section 33, as the case may be;
authorized body (獲授權機構) means the person appointed by the Secretary for Justice under section 98ZT(2);
Cap. 159 (《第159章》) means the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159);
code of practice (實務守則) means the code of practice issued under section 98ZN and as amended from time to time;
conditional fee agreement (按條件收費協議)—see section 98ZC;
damages-based agreement (按損害賠償收費協議)—see section 98ZD;
emergency arbitrator (緊急仲裁員) has the meaning given by section 22A;
expenses (開支) means—(a)disbursements incurred by a lawyer, or directly by a client of the lawyer, in a matter; or(b)any legal expenses insurance premium incurred by a client;
financial benefit (財務利益)—(a)means any money or money’s worth; but(b)does not include—(i)any sum awarded in respect of a lawyer’s costs; and(ii)any sum awarded in respect of expenses;
hybrid damages-based agreement (混合式按損害賠償收費協議)—see section 98ZE;

lawyer (律師) means—(a)a person who is enrolled on the roll of barristers kept under section 29 of Cap. 159;(b)a person who is enrolled on the roll of solicitors kept under section 5 of Cap. 159; or(c)a person who is qualified to practise the law of a jurisdiction other than Hong Kong, including a foreign lawyer as defined by section 2(1) of Cap. 159;
mediation proceedings (調解程序) means mediation proceedings referred to in section 32(3) or 33;
ORFS means outcome related fee structure;
ORFS agreement (ORFS協議)—see section 98ZB.

section.name: s98ZB
section.heading: Meaning of ORFS agreement

subsection.leadIn: An ORFS agreement is any of the following agreements made between a client and a lawyer of the client—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a conditional fee agreement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a damages-based agreement;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a hybrid damages-based agreement.

subsection.leadIn: A reference to an ORFS agreement for arbitration in this Part is a reference to an ORFS agreement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: made between a client and a lawyer of the client for an arbitration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: made on or after the day on which Divisions 3, 4 and 7 have all come into operation.

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, an ORFS agreement for arbitration is not to be construed to include a funding agreement within the meaning of Part 10A.

section.name: s98ZC
section.heading: Meaning of conditional fee agreement

subsection.content: A conditional fee agreement is an agreement, made for a matter between a client and a lawyer of the client, under which the lawyer agrees with the client to be paid a success fee for the matter only in the event of a successful outcome for the client in the matter.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)—
subsection.def: successful outcome (成果), in relation to a client in a matter—(a)means any outcome of the matter falling within the description of being successful as agreed to between the client and a lawyer of the client; and(b)includes any financial benefit that is obtained by the client in the matter.

section.name: s98ZD
section.heading: Meaning of damages-based agreement
section.leadIn: A damages-based agreement is an agreement, made between a client and a lawyer of the client for a matter, under which—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the DBA payment is calculated by reference to the financial benefit that is obtained by the client in the matter.

section.name: s98ZE
section.heading: Meaning of hybrid damages-based agreement
section.leadIn: A hybrid damages-based agreement is an agreement, made between a client and a lawyer of the client for a matter, under which the lawyer agrees with the client to be paid for the matter—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the event the client obtains a financial benefit in the matter—a payment calculated by reference to the financial benefit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any event—a fee, which may or may not be calculated at a discount, for the legal services rendered by the lawyer for the client during the course of the matter.

division.name: D3
division.heading: ORFS Agreements for Arbitration Not Prohibited by Particular Common Law Offences or Tort

section.name: s98ZF
section.heading: Particular common law offences do not apply
section.content: The common law offences of maintenance (including the common law offence of champerty) and of being a common barrator do not apply in relation to an ORFS agreement for arbitration.

section.name: s98ZG
section.heading: Particular tort does not apply
section.content: The tort of maintenance (including the tort of champerty) does not apply in relation to an ORFS agreement for arbitration.

section.name: s98ZH
section.heading: Other illegality not affected
section.content: Sections 98ZF and 98ZG do not affect any rule of law as to the cases in which a contract is to be treated as contrary to public policy or otherwise illegal.

section.name: s98ZI
section.heading: Application of Part 10B for non-Hong Kong arbitration
section.content: Despite section 5, this Part applies in relation to an arbitration for which the place of arbitration is outside Hong Kong or there is no place of arbitration as if the place of arbitration were in Hong Kong.

division.name: D4
division.heading: General Provisions for ORFS Agreements for Arbitration

section.name: s98ZJ
section.heading: Application of Division 4
section.content: This Division applies in relation to an ORFS agreement for arbitration.

section.name: s98ZK
section.heading: Validity and enforceability of ORFS agreements for arbitration

subsection.leadIn: An ORFS agreement for arbitration that meets—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all general conditions specified in the rules; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all specific conditions specified in the rules for the kind of ORFS agreement to which the agreement belongs,

subsection.continued: is not void or unenforceable only because of its being an ORFS agreement for arbitration.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)—
subsection.def: rules (規則) means rules made by the advisory body under section 98ZM.

section.name: s98ZL
section.heading: ORFS agreement for arbitration void and unenforceable to extent relating to personal injuries claim

subsection.content: Despite section 98ZK, an ORFS agreement for arbitration is void and unenforceable to the extent that it relates to a personal injuries claim.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: personal injuries (人身傷害) includes any disease and any impairment of a person’s physical or mental condition;
personal injuries claim (人身傷害申索) means a claim brought under the common law for damages in respect of personal injuries to the claimant or any other person or in respect of a person’s death.

section.name: s98ZM
section.heading: Power of advisory body to make rules for matters under Part 10B

subsection.leadIn: The advisory body may, in consultation with the Secretary for Justice and with the prior approval of the Chief Justice, make rules for any or all of the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to specify the general conditions for the purposes of section 98ZK(1)(a);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to specify the specific conditions for the purposes of section 98ZK(1)(b);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to generally provide for the effective implementation of the purposes and provisions of this Part.

subsection.leadIn: Any rules made under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be of general application or make different provisions for different cases or classes of cases; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may include the incidental, supplementary and consequential provisions that the advisory body considers necessary or expedient.

section.name: s98ZN
section.heading: Code of practice may be issued

subsection.content: The authorized body may issue a code of practice setting out the practices and standards with which lawyers who enter into ORFS agreements for arbitration are ordinarily expected to comply in connection with those agreements.
The authorized body must publish the code of practice in the Gazette.
The code of practice comes into operation on the day on which it is published in the Gazette.
The code of practice is not subsidiary legislation.
The authorized body may amend or revoke the code of practice.
Subsections (2), (3) and (4) apply in relation to an amendment or revocation of the code of practice in the same way as they apply in relation to the code of practice.

section.name: s98ZO
section.heading: Non-compliance with code of practice

subsection.content: A failure to comply with a provision of the code of practice does not, of itself, render any person liable to any judicial or other proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: However—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the code of practice is admissible in evidence in proceedings before any court or arbitral tribunal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any compliance, or failure to comply, with a provision of the code of practice may be taken into account by any court or arbitral tribunal if it is relevant to a question being decided by the court or arbitral tribunal.

section.name: s98ZP
section.heading: Communication of information for ORFS agreements for arbitration

subsection.content: Despite section 18(1), information referred to in that section may be communicated by a party to a lawyer for the purpose of entering into, or seeking to enter into, an ORFS agreement for arbitration with the lawyer.

subsection.leadIn: However, the lawyer may not further communicate anything communicated under subsection (1), unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the further communication is made—

subparagraph.content: to protect or pursue a legal right or interest of the lawyer; or
to enforce or challenge an award made in the arbitration,

paragraph.continued: in legal proceedings before a court or other judicial authority in or outside Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the further communication is made to a professional adviser of the lawyer for the purpose of obtaining advice in connection with the ORFS agreement for arbitration.

subsection.content: If a further communication is made by a lawyer to a professional adviser under subsection (2)(c), subsection (2) applies to the professional adviser as if the professional adviser were the lawyer.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: communicate (傳達) includes publish or disclose.

section.name: s98ZQ
section.heading: Disclosure about ORFS agreement for arbitration

subsection.leadIn: If an ORFS agreement for arbitration is made between a client and a lawyer of the client, the lawyer must give written notice of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the fact that an ORFS agreement for arbitration has been made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name of the client.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for an ORFS agreement for arbitration made on or before the commencement of the arbitration—on the commencement of the arbitration; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for an ORFS agreement for arbitration made after the commencement of the arbitration—within 15 days after the agreement is made.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each other party to the arbitration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the arbitration body.

subsection.content: For subsection (3)(b), if there is no arbitration body for the arbitration at the time, or at the end of the period, specified in subsection (2) for giving the notice, the notice must instead be given to the arbitration body immediately after there is an arbitration body for the arbitration.

section.name: s98ZR
section.heading: Disclosure about end of ORFS agreement for arbitration

subsection.leadIn: If an ORFS agreement for arbitration ends (other than because of the end of the arbitration), the client must give written notice of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the fact that the agreement has ended; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date the agreement ended.

subsection.content: The notice must be given within 15 days after the ORFS agreement for arbitration ends.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must be given to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each other party to the arbitration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the arbitration body (if any).

section.name: s98ZS
section.heading: Non-compliance with Division 7

subsection.content: A failure to comply with this Division does not, of itself, render any person liable to any judicial or other proceedings.

However, any compliance, or failure to comply, with this Division may be taken into account by any court or arbitral tribunal if it is relevant to a question being decided by the court or arbitral tribunal.

section.name: s98ZT
section.heading: Appointment of advisory body and authorized body

subsection.content: The Secretary for Justice may, by notice published in the Gazette, appoint as the advisory body a person the Secretary for Justice considers appropriate to monitor and review the operation of this Part and exercise the power under section 98ZM.
The Secretary for Justice may, by notice published in the Gazette, appoint as the authorized body a person the Secretary for Justice considers appropriate to exercise the powers under section 98ZN.

section.name: s98ZU
section.heading: Limitation on award of costs by arbitral tribunal

subsection.content: Despite section 74(3), an arbitral tribunal may not order costs specified in subsection (3) to be paid to a party to an arbitration if an ORFS agreement for arbitration has been entered into between the party and a lawyer of the party for the arbitration.
However, the arbitral tribunal may still order those costs to be paid to a party to the arbitration if satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances justifying the ordering of those costs.

subsection.leadIn: The costs are those that fall within any of the following descriptions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the ORFS agreement for the arbitration is a conditional fee agreement—the success fee as defined by section 98ZC(2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any legal expenses insurance premium;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any part of the fee that is in excess of the fee that the lawyer would have been entitled to be paid by the party if there had been no ORFS agreement for the arbitration (normal fee).

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, this section does not prevent the arbitral tribunal from ordering a party to the arbitration to pay costs in an amount not exceeding the amount of the normal fee.

part.name: P11
part.heading: Provisions that may be Expressly Opted for or Automatically Apply

section.name: s99
section.heading: Arbitration agreements may provide expressly for opt-in provisions
section.leadIn: An arbitration agreement may provide expressly that any or all of the following provisions are to apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 1 of Schedule 2;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 2 of Schedule 2;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 3 of Schedule 2;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: sections 4 and 7 of Schedule 2;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: sections 5, 6 and 7 of Schedule 2.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Opt-in provisions automatically apply in certain cases
section.leadIn: All the provisions in Schedule 2 apply, subject to section 102, to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an arbitration agreement entered into before the commencement of this Ordinance which has provided that arbitration under the agreement is a domestic arbitration; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an arbitration agreement entered into at any time within a period of 6 years after the commencement of this Ordinance which provides that arbitration under the agreement is a domestic arbitration.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Opt-in provisions that automatically apply under section 100 deemed to apply to Hong Kong construction subcontracting cases

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all the provisions in Schedule 2 apply under section 100(a) or (b) to an arbitration agreement, in any form referred to in section 19, included in a construction contract;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the whole or any part of the construction operations to be carried out under the construction contract (relevant operation) is subcontracted to any person under another construction contract (subcontract); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that subcontract also includes an arbitration agreement (subcontracting parties’ arbitration agreement) in any form referred to in section 19,

subsection.continued: then all the provisions in Schedule 2 also apply, subject to section 102, to the subcontracting parties’ arbitration agreement.

subsection.leadIn: Unless the subcontracting parties’ arbitration agreement is an arbitration agreement referred to in section 100(a) or (b), subsection (1) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the person to whom the whole or any part of the relevant operation is subcontracted under the subcontract is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a natural person who is ordinarily resident outside Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: incorporated under the law of a place outside Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the central management and control of which is exercised outside Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: formed under the law of a place outside Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the central management and control of which is exercised outside Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person to whom the whole or any part of the relevant operation is subcontracted under the subcontract has no place of business in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a substantial part of the relevant operation which is subcontracted under the subcontract is to be performed outside Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all the provisions in Schedule 2 apply to a subcontracting parties’ arbitration agreement under subsection (1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the whole or any part of the relevant operation that is subcontracted under the subcontract is further subcontracted to another person under a further construction contract (further subcontract); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that further subcontract also includes an arbitration agreement in any form referred to in section 19,

subsection.continued: subsection (1) has effect subject to subsection (2), and all the provisions in Schedule 2 apply, subject to section 102, to the arbitration agreement so included in that further subcontract as if that further subcontract were a subcontract under subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: construction contract (建造合約) has the meaning given to it by section 2(1) of the Construction Industry Council Ordinance (Cap. 587);
construction operations (建造工程) has the meaning given to it by Schedule 1 to the Construction Industry Council Ordinance (Cap. 587).

section.name: s102
section.heading: Circumstances under which opt-in provisions not automatically apply

subsection.leadIn: Sections 100 and 101 do not apply if— (Amended 11 of 2015 s. 4)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the parties to the arbitration agreement concerned so agree in writing; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the arbitration agreement concerned has provided expressly that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: section 100 or 101 does not apply; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: section 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 or 7 of Schedule 2 applies or does not apply. (Amended 11 of 2015 s. 4)

subsection.content: Subsection (1)(b)(ii) does not derogate from the operation of section 99. (Added 11 of 2015 s. 4)

section.name: s103
section.heading: Application of provisions under this Part
section.content: If there is any conflict or inconsistency between any provision that applies under this Part and any other provision of this Ordinance, the first-mentioned provision prevails, to the extent of the conflict or inconsistency, over that other provision.

part.name: P11A
part.heading: Arbitrations Relating to Intellectual Property Rights

section.name: s103A
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: IPR (知識產權)—see section 103B;
IPR dispute (知識產權爭議)—see section 103C.

section.name: s103B
section.heading: Interpretation: IPR

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, an intellectual property right (IPR) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a patent;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a trade mark;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a geographical indication;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a design;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a copyright or related right;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a domain name;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a layout-design (topography) of integrated circuit;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a plant variety right;
a right in confidential information, trade secret or know-how;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: a right to protect goodwill by way of passing off or similar action against unfair competition; or

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: any other IPR of whatever nature.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, a reference to an IPR is a reference to such an IPR—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether or not the IPR is protectible by registration; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether or not the IPR is registered, or subsists, in Hong Kong.

subsection.content: In this Part, a reference to an IPR includes an application for the registration of an IPR if the IPR is protectible by registration.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
